body: She is loath to go into detail, but Amanda M. Burden is clearly not crazy about the design for a Jets stadium on the Far West Side of Manhattan. As director of the City Planning Department, she has built her reputation on concern for aesthetics: how a building looks, how it relates to the street, how it serves the people who use its public spaces.
title: An Aesthetic Watchdog in the City Planning Office

body: Now, You Can Eat With Your Hands The elegant century-old fixtures are still there, but now they serve as background for Buffalo wings and Philly cheesesteaks instead of Charleston she-crab soup and belly clams. Last February, Gage & Tollner, the landmark restaurant in Downtown Brooklyn that had been in business since 1879, shut its doors because of
title: FOLLOWING UP

body: After several false starts, state and city officials are set to sign off on a new, final master plan for the Downtown Brooklyn waterfront that would include playing fields, a marina, stores and a new residential and commercial hub at the foot of Atlantic Avenue. The plan for the 1.3-mile shoreline park from Dumbo to Cobble Hill is a crucial step
title: Brooklyn Waterfront Park Inches Closer

body: The boxer Mike Tyson has completed the community service sentence he received for his role in a brawl in a Brooklyn hotel last year, Judge John W. Carter of Criminal Court in Brooklyn ruled yesterday. Mr. Tyson served at least 100 hours, much of it teaching boxing to youngsters at a community center in Phoenix, said a spokesman for the Brooklyn
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Tyson Completes Community Service

body: A subway worker responsible for flagging train operators to get them to slow down in a work zone was himself struck and killed by a train in Brooklyn yesterday as other members of his work crew reacted in horror. It was the first fatal accident involving a transit worker this year. The worker, identified by transit officials as Harold Dozier, 54,
title: Worker Killed by Subway on Tracks in Brooklyn

body: A sampling of the musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.) This selection, compiled by Jeremy Eichler, represents what caught this critic's eye and excited his expectations. More holiday recommendations for this weekend are
title: 'Messiahs' Here, 'Glorias' There, Holiday Music Is Everywhere

body: Transportation advocates and politicians yesterday called for free street-level transfers between subway stations in Downtown Brooklyn. They said such transfers would be comparable to similar arrangements in Manhattan and Queens. But transit officials said such expanded transfers may cost as much as $90 million annually. The Tri-State
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Free Subway Transfers Urged

body: For many companies and their lobbyists, the cost of doing business with the City Council already includes the obligatory round of fund-raisers and receptions for its 51 members. Now comes another big-ticket event: the Council holiday party. Admission to the annual festivities at the Surrogates Courthouse, set for Thursday this year, has soared to
title: Invitation to Council's Holiday Party Comes at a Price

body: A program that helps newly paroled prisoners will expand its services today, offering them drug and alcohol counseling, job training, medical care and other services under one roof in downtown Brooklyn, said Jerry Schmetterer, a spokesman for District Attorney Charles J. Hynes, left. Previously, Mr. Schmetterer said, the process of ''re-entry'' to
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Program To Help Parolees Expands

body: WHAT do the soaring prices of works by Gauguin and Warhol have to do with the ever-rising price of condominiums in New York? Perhaps nothing at all. After all, a picture hook does not make a home. But that hasn't stopped developers and their sales teams from aggressively seizing the cachet of the art world and using it to promote their latest and
title: In New Buildings, Buying Into Cool

body: To the Editor: Your Nov. 14 editorial ''Saving the Sound'' correctly points out the need for New York City to improve its sewage treatment plants to reduce pollution in Long Island Sound. But even more pressing is the need to eliminate or reduce overflows that release some 27 billion gallons of untreated sewage into New York Harbor each year. These
title: Sewage Overflow In City's Water

body: IT was a little after 11:30 in the morning -- a chilly, wet Saturday in November -- and already the line outside the high-rise, 12-screen multiplex in downtown Brooklyn had stretched around the block. My companions and I took our spots and hunched our shoulders against the wind. Though it was, technically, my day off, I was pulling a little
title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; Making Movies for The Ages, All Ages

body: Some people seek their calling. For others, like Dov Charney, it is bred in the bone. ''I think I was born a hustler,'' said Mr. Charney, the fast-talking founder of American Apparel, the rapidly expanding youth-oriented T-shirt chain. ''I like the hustle. I like selling a product that people love. It's nice when a girl tries on a bra or a tie-dye
title: Building a Brand by Not Being a Brand

body: LIKE a leaf pressed between the pages of a book and come upon again years later, a 4,000-square-foot apartment that recently went on sale at the San Remo on Central Park West has been preserved with few changes since the majestic apartment building, designed by Emery Roth, went up in 1930. The apartment is being sold by the family of Nadia Jaglom,
title: BIG DEAL; Park Views and a Fancy Shower Available at the San Remo

body: The ruins of the World Trade Center were still burning when federal agents arrested two men at Kennedy Airport who were found with more than $140,000 hidden in cardboard boxes with honey jars bound for Yemen. For the agents, aware that terrorists were said to use honey shipments to hide money, that slender lead could not be ignored. If the world
title: Behind Scenes, Informer's Path Led U.S. to 20 Terror Cases

body: It is time for dinner at Metro Club in Brooklyn, and a spicy scent wafts through its airy rooms. Caesar Quiñones has made his special chicken curry, and his diners are drifting toward the kitchen, ready for the meal. For Mr. Quiñones, 52, cooking is more than a necessary pleasure or even a stress reliever. It is a diversion from his severe
title: The Neediest Cases; In Preparing Spicy Meals, He Keeps Depression at Bay

body: EVERY Friday at 3 p.m., a flood erupts from the doors of Manhattan Center for Science and Mathematics High School in Spanish Harlem and surges down East 116th Street. It is composed of teenagers in every manner of dress, yelling, laughing, jumping on each other, flirting, eating cheeseburgers, and playing catch, consumed with the joy that is the
title: The Smart Sport

title: Spare Times

body: A handful of commuters showed up at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority public hearing here on Wednesday to tell the agency that no fare increase -- no matter what size -- was acceptable. Facing a multibillion-dollar budget gap, the authority has proposed raising subway, bus and train fares this year. In its most recent proposal, it seeks to
title: Commuters Say No Increase Is Justified for M.T.A. Fares

title: Spare Times

body: Striking a characteristic New York pose near Lincoln Center yesterday, Beverly Camhe clutched three morning newspapers to her chest while balancing a large latte and talked about how disconsolate she was to realize that not only had her candidate, John Kerry, lost but that she and her city were so out of step with the rest of the country. ''Do you
title: A Blue City (Disconsolate, Even) Bewildered by a Red America

body: MANY ARE CALLED By Walker Evans. Introduction by James Agee. Foreword by Luc Sante. 207 pp. Metropolitan Museum of Art/Yale University Press. $40. The New York City subway rumbled into existence a century ago this month, and on the first day of operation, Oct. 27, 1904, a man told a newspaper reporter something remarkably prescient about the
title: Petals on a Wet Black Bough

body: Maybe the idea of financing a new stadium here for the relocated Montreal Expos seemed easy last month when the city received the news that Major League Baseball would send the team to the nation's capital. The celebratory rally was led by the bow-tied Mayor Anthony A. Williams, who wore a red Senators cap, John Fogerty's song ''Centerfield''
title: BASEBALL; Problems for New Washington Team

body: JACOBS -- Joseph J. The Board of Trustees, administration, faculty, students and alumni of Polytechnic University mourn the passing of Dr. Joseph J. Jacobs, alumnus, generous benefactor and 1986 Honorary Doctorate of Engineering recipient of the University. He twice served as chairman of Polytechnic's Board of Trustees and was a lifetime trustee.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths JACOBS, JOSEPH J.

author: Joanna Smith Rakoff, a contributing editor and columnist for Poets and Writers magazine, is completing a novel set in Brooklyn.
body: ON a rainy night in April, a 24-year-old New Yorker named Jill Pittman left her weekly Bible study group in East Harlem, walked across town and took the subway to Harlem, where she shared an apartment with a college friend. As she walked home along her usual route, one block south on Lenox Avenue, and one block west on 134th Street, a hand closed
title: Is New York Losing Its Street Smarts?

body: Recreation New York City BICYCLE TOUR OF BROOKLYN'S CARNEGIE LIBRARIES, a 10-mile ride to three branches of the Brooklyn Public Libraries that were created with funds from Andrew Carnegie: the Pacific, Williamsburgh and Bedford branches. Meets tomorrow at 11 a.m., rain or shine, in front of the Central Library at Grand Army Plaza. Sponsored by the
title: SPARE TIMES

body: Whose hands made this wall, the history books do not tell. Faceless lunch-pail carriers stacked these bricks and stones, men made briefly strong with twice-daily naval rations of grog, a roughly even mixture of water and rum. They are gone, but their wall remains, ambling around what were swamps and mud flats in their day, standing as their cairn
title: Peeking Over the Wall At the End of Brooklyn; The Navy Is Long Gone, but a Barrier Remains

body: ''You get more than rides with a 30-day MetroCard,'' the subway advertisements read, promoting what the Metropolitan Transportation Authority presents as the card's convenience and value, in the form of discounts for the regular subway rider. But that discount could all but disappear for many New Yorkers if the authority acts on its proposal to
title: 30-Day Card Will Yield Less Saving In Subways

body: While many parts of Brooklyn have been experiencing well-publicized revivals, this is not the case in the worn commercial area at the intersection of Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues in the Midwood section. Now, however, a Queens developer is preparing to construct a three-story retail complex anchored by a Target store on the site, formerly owned by
title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Brooklyn; 3-Story Shopping Complex For Area Short on Retailing

body: LATE on a recent Saturday night in the subway station underneath Nassau Avenue in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, a long-awaited G train pulled up to the platform, drawing applause and a short little dance from two relieved young women who had been waiting. The applause was tinged with sarcasm, and it was typical. The subway line, which weaves its way
title: URBAN TACTICS; The Cinderella Train

body: To the Editor: Arthur Levine, the president of Teachers College at Columbia, is on the right track with ''Failing the Grade System'' (Op-Ed, Sept. 26). Grouping students in ''bridge'' classes -- by ability rather than age or grade -- would result in substantial long-term gains. We need to create these classes in kindergarten or during the day-care
title: Students Learn at Different Rates. Now What?

body: Bruce C. Ratner, left, the new owner of the New Jersey Nets, announced yesterday that he would enter into a formal agreement to provide community benefits as part of the large project he wants to build in downtown Brooklyn, which includes a new arena for the Nets, housing and commercial space. The agreement, which he expects to complete next month,
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Developer Vows To Benefit Community

body: Usmanu Salisu surveyed the tabletop scene: potatoes, apples, watermelons and squash. ''This is good, real good, and it's all fresh,'' Mr. Salisu said, inspecting a ripe Cortland apple. ''I don't see it this good at the supermarket.'' That's just what Ena Nemley wants to hear. Every week, Ms. Nemley rounds up green beans and collard greens from the
title: Bleak Landscapes, Green Produce; Poor Neighborhoods See Rise in Farmers' Markets

body: The notion of shopping for minimalist furniture while nibbling Swedish meatballs within view of the Statue of Liberty took a major step forward yesterday as a City Council panel approved a plan for what is likely to become New York City's first Ikea, along the Brooklyn waterfront in Red Hook. The approval came despite opposition from some residents
title: Panel Approves Plan by Ikea To Open Store In Red Hook

body: BUZZY O'KEEFE'S foie gras vendors thought he was nuts when he opened the tony River Cafe in the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge in 1977. ''Everybody in New York said I was out of my mind, that nobody would come to Brooklyn,'' he said. ''When I first opened up,'' he added, ''they were afraid.'' That was then. Now that once-grotty waterfront parcel is
title: LIVING IN/Brooklyn Heights; A Graceful Bastion in a Swirling Borough

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 36-01 35th Avenue, at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens. One of the largest collections of moving-image artifacts. body: Transit workers fanned out to spots throughout the city yesterday, girding for rain. Their mission was simple: to stave off another paralysis of the city's subway system like what occurred on Sept. 8 during the morning rush and again on Sept. 18, because of flooding. On Monday, four teams of workers, one for each borough the subway runs through,
title: Subways Remain Vulnerable To Flooding

body: A year ago at the Atlantic Antic, the huge annual street fair on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, representatives from a consortium of civic groups announced a far-reaching master plan to mold the street's westernmost end into the grand urban boulevard of their imagination. The festival celebrates its 30th anniversary today, and the 600,000 or so
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; A Boulevard of Dreams, Unfolding Step by Step

body: To the Editor: In ''The Wait Continues at Touro Law School'' (Long Island Journal, Sept. 19), the school's new dean, Lawrence Raful, is quoted as stating, ''We will be the only law school in the country that will be located right next door to federal and state courthouses.'' As a graduate of Brooklyn Law School, I would like to make note of the
title: Touro Law School Is Special, but Not Unique

body: The old Italian-American men in Carroll Park rise with old-men efforts from their plastic chairs to see over the low concrete wall into the narrow clay court where red and green balls bounce and roll and knock about. Their game taxes the same skills as any child's play, a lot of hand-eye coordination and a little strategy, but it is their game.
title: A Crossover Moment for an Old World Game; In a New Tournament and a City Bar, Boccie Gets a Makeover

body: As Haiti, battered by a tropical storm, struggles to recover, workers at the Flatbush Haitian Center are raising money to help pay for clean water. The Haitian Centers Council in downtown Brooklyn, along with 13 firehouses throughout the city, is collecting food to send to a place where yesterday people remained hungry atop their houses, still
title: Brooklyn Haitians Rally Again for Flooded Homeland

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. title: SPARE TIMES

body: In the busy 67th Precinct in Flatbush, Brooklyn, Detectives Patrick H. Rafferty and Robert L. Parker came together to form the backbone of their team. Strong men with big personalities, they were, their fellow detectives say, the mentors, the ones to call for especially tough situations in what has long been one of the city's most violent
title: Worlds Apart, Two Detectives Worked and Died Together

body: The cunning bicycle thieves of New York City always seem to be one step ahead of lockmakers. Design a more sophisticated lock and the thieves make a better pick. Make a sturdier chain and they get bigger bolt cutters. And if all else fails, they just dig up the parking meter or stop sign to unshackle the bike from it. But to open some of the
title: The Pen Is Mightier Than the Lock; A Ballpoint Trick Infuriates Bicyclists

body: Not far from Spuyten Duyvil, the junction of the Harlem and Hudson Rivers in northern Manhattan, two commercial development trends have also converged: a big-box retailer with a major suburban presence has established an urban beachhead and in the process desolate industrial land has been given a much more lucrative reuse. The result is River
title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Bronx; A Major Retail Presence Just North of Manhattan

body: ''Hi -- what school are you here for?'' Les Ford, the sweet-voiced man standing by the front door, asked as students arrived yesterday morning for the opening of classes. title: A Calm, but Confusing, First Day of School

Yet the United States Open, one of the premier events of professional tennis, and downtown
title: Ethnic Food, Anyone? After Tennis, Flushing Calls

body: THE building at the southwest corner of 14th Street and University Place near Union Square Park has been a J. W. May's department store and, more recently, a Bradlees. title: SQUARE FEET/Union Square; A Shopping Destination for the Young and Hip

body: THE little airplane bobs and dips and yaws in the thermals rising around the southern tip of Flatbush Avenue; you can feel the warm air lifting the riveted aluminum wings. To the right, Brooklyn is stretched out in the haze like a diorama: the houses on Mill Basin with cabin cruisers tied to their docks; the receding avenues; and in the distance,
title: Sky Above, Hubbub Below

body: ''Ladies and Gentlemen '' IF Jimmy Baez (short, black hair, mustache, gold earring) breezed by you on the sidewalk, you would not notice. If you overheard him talking to his girlfriend, you probably would not turn around. title: CITYPEOPLE; A Voice in the Crowd

body: WHEN Amy Walsh of Commack heard a few months ago that the Republican National Convention would be held at Madison Square Garden beginning Aug. 30, she quickly booked her vacation for that week. ''I'm going to Cancún to stay away from the convention,'' Ms. Walsh, a legal secretary for Icahn Associates at Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, said as she
title: Delegates In, Commuters Out

title: In Brooklyn, Bribery Trial Opens Against Court Aides

body: Though the pronunciation varies, the name Chuck E. Cheese is the same in every language. And on a recent Saturday, it could be heard bouncing off the walls of the new Atlantic Terminal mall in downtown Brooklyn in at least a half-dozen accents. ''It's up there, it's up there!'' a boy of about 3 repeated to his harried-looking mother as they tried
title: Sampling Suburbia Inside a Brooklyn Mall

title: Sports of The Times; Yanks Blazing On a Sunny Afternoon

body: IN the last week of July, on a steamy evening, Sandra Bernhard was holding forth in downtown Brooklyn at the new Target, entertaining the hundreds of guests who had come to celebrate the store's opening. It was a significant moment for a number of reasons. The Target is part of the Atlantic Terminal, a new mall built by Forest City Ratner. It is
title: SQUARE FEET/Downtown Brooklyn; At Site Dodgers Rejected, Target Store Is a Hit

body: With condominium prices soaring, Mario Procida, a seasoned developer from the Bronx, decided that the building he was putting up at 53 Boerum Place in the first of a swath of residential buildings going up on the edge of downtown Brooklyn could make it as a condominium, rather than a rental. So he put in the usual condo upgrades: a 24-hour
title: POSTINGS; Where High-Tech And Luxury Meet

author: RANDY KENNEDY reports on cultural news for The Times.
body: New York City is not considered a first-class convention town, for good reason. The Jacob K. Javits Convention Center is too far out of the way and too small, with only a third of the convention space that Chicago offers. And as storied as it is, even Madison Square Garden, where the Republican National Convention will be held from Aug. 30 to Sept.
title: WHAT'S DOING IN; New York

body: BARNES & NOBLE has cappuccino; Amazon.com has one-click ordering; Google has more than four billion Web pages. So why venture out to the Brooklyn Public Library's 1941 main building, at Flatbush Avenue and Eastern Parkway? Well, the digital age has not yet killed the library, and this one has three million titles, as well as something that cannot
title: STREETSCAPES/Brooklyn Public Library; A Living Monument To the Power of the Word

body: What was remarkable about the last day of the year at Community Prep, New York City's first public high school for students who have been recently released from juvenile prisons and jails, was that 27 students -- a little more than a third of the roster -- stayed around for the final assembly. Gathered in the basement of the school, which occupies
title: Last Chance High; Young Offenders Find Hope, Guardedly, in the Classroom

body: AS the rookie owner of the Nets, Bruce C. Ratner found himself last week in a pressurized position not unfamiliar to his point man, Jason Kidd. Ratner had the ball in his hands with time running out, boxed in a bind. Unlike Kidd, the real estate developer doesn't have eyes in the back of his head. New to the game, Ratner never saw the Denver
title: Sports of the Times; Nets' Future Is an Arena In Brooklyn

body: As a Muslim immigrant growing up in New York, Navila Ali, 20, felt safe and almost American until Sept. 11, 2001, she said yesterday, speaking out at an unusual public hearing led by the bishop of Brooklyn to highlight the impact of enforcement crackdowns on the city's immigrants. Ms. Ali's father, a bookseller, was required to register with the
title: From Immigrants, Stories Of Scrutiny, and Struggle

body: From Stage to Start-Up And Maybe Back Again The script got away from the playwright. In 1991, the singer, actress and playwright Gretchen Cryer moved onto a new stage. She opened a business that shipped freshly made meals to people across the country who were disabled, homebound or just too busy or stove-challenged to cook, but who wanted their
title: FOLLOWING UP

body: Decades-long efforts to develop Long Island City as a major office district received a bit of a boost last week with the news that Citigroup would move 700 employees from Lower Manhattan into a planned new 14-story building across the street from the company's 48-story tower, which has stood in splendid isolation since the late 1980's. Still, the
title: SQUARE FEET/Long Island City; An Office District Slow in Emerging

body: A report that a man was sitting yesterday with a bomblike device strapped to him near a busy intersection in downtown Brooklyn prompted the police to shut down traffic and evacuate hundreds of people, the authorities said. The device turned out to be harmless, and no one was hurt. The people evacuated from the intersection, where Court Street meets
title: Real Concern, Caused by a Bomb That Wasn't

body: A federal judge sentenced a New Jersey man yesterday to the maximum five years in prison for lying to investigators during an investigation of terrorism financing efforts that they said were centered in Brooklyn. Federal prosecutors described the sentence as an important victory because it showed that judges would impose stiff penalties on people
title: Man Gets 5 Years for Lying in Terror Inquiry

body: In the late 1990's, Rhonnie Jaus, chief of the sex crimes bureau at the Brooklyn district attorney's office, found herself prosecuting a case involving an 11-year-old prostitute, the youngest she had seen in her many years in the bureau. The 11-year-old was one of four prostitutes, none older than 15, whom Ms. Jaus wanted to testify against their
title: Offering Young Prostitutes Chance to Stay Out of Jail

body: DEAR DIARY: On a recent Saturday evening, after dinner at an Asian-fusion restaurant, watermelon martinis at a hip downtown bar, and a live jazz show, I thought to myself that I had just had a quintessential ''Sex and the City'' New York evening. Hopping on the 6 train to head home, I was even more excited to get a seat. At the next stop, an
title: Metropolitan Diary

body: The idea of bringing a professional sports team to the city almost always sounds great -- and then the calculation of cost versus benefits begins. It seems a new team requires a new sports facility, and for some reason, owners of these lucrative franchises are seldom willing to build anything without enormous infusions of public money. That is one
title: The Brooklyn Nets

body: To walk in and around the Fulton Mall in Downtown Brooklyn is to be confronted with the visual cacophony of a fraying commercial hub. Along this block, a pastiche of racy magazine covers gives way to the tropical-themed neon of a cellphone store. Over there, glittering swaths of gold jewelry are punctuated by advertisements for human-hair wigs and
title: In a Ragtag Hub, Look Up, For There's Beauty Above

body: The usual concert season in New York lasts from September to June, but for those who like to make concertgoing an adventure -- and don't like to pay much for their adventures -- the best time of year is summer. Opera stars emote at the Met in the Parks series, world music luminaries head to Central and Prospect Parks, and the hottest names in indie
title: When a Park Turns Into a Soundscape

body: In an effort to ease the parking shortage in downtown Brooklyn, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday that more than 110 parking spots currently reserved for city agency vehicles would be eliminated by the fall. In their place, the mayor said, the city will carve out 40 metered parking spaces, 50 spaces on residential streets that are
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: More Downtown Parking

body: The City Council took a major step in remaking Downtown Brooklyn yesterday, formally approving an ambitious rezoning package that is intended to encourage commercial and residential development as part of the city's efforts to attract and keep jobs within the five boroughs. ''This plan will go a long way toward creating a vibrant downtown in
title: A Plan Passes And an Arena Is Protested In Brooklyn

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday promoted Frank P. Cruthers, chief of department for the Fire Department of New York, to first deputy commissioner of the Fire Department. Peter E. Hayden, assistant chief of operations, will become the next chief of department. As first deputy commissioner, Mr. Cruthers will oversee the department's
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Top Fire Department Appointments

body: The marquee at the Flatbush Pavilion movie theater was still in place last week, advertising a couple of big Hollywood flops called ''Van Helsing'' and ''Man on Fire.'' But on a sunny Wednesday afternoon, the only line in front of the theater was the one for the B-41 bus. The Pavilion, on Flatbush Avenue off Seventh Avenue in Prospect Heights,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROSPECT HEIGHTS; Coming Attractions? Well, None, Actually

title: New Match for Developer of Harlem Project

body: Medium Rare Q. This winter the Tad's Steaks on 42nd Street east of Seventh Avenue closed to make way for construction of the Bank of America tower. I remember when there were Tad's all over the place. Is the chain still in business? A. Tad's is grilling away at three Manhattan locations: Seventh Avenue at 47th Street, Seventh Avenue at 50th Street
title: F.Y.I.

author: Michael Shapiro's most recent book is ''The Last Good Season: Brooklyn, the Dodgers and Their Final Pennant Race Together'' (Doubleday, 2003).
body: I grew up a Yankee fan, if only by default, and I stayed that way for a very long time. The Yankees were the only team in town in 1961 when I became aware of baseball and of loyalties. The Dodgers and the Giants were gone and the Mets were still a year away. I followed the Yankees, even though I grew up in Brooklyn. And I stayed with them. That is,
title: BackTalk; Aging Has Made One Heart Grow Fonder for the Mets

body: The Atlantic Center mall is not like other malls. Instead of open, multilevel atriums where dozens of storefronts are easily captured by the naked consumerist eye, there are vast expanses of nothingness and dead corridors leading, it seems, to nowhere. In place of furnished common areas offering respite between purchasing bouts, there are broad
title: Different by Design, Soon to Be Less So; Rethinking Atlantic Center With the Customer in Mind

body: Dozens of suspected members of a violent drug ring that the authorities say has virtually held a Brooklyn housing project hostage for the last several years have been indicted on conspiracy and attempted murder charges, law enforcement officials said yesterday. Over four years, prosecutors and police said, a group of drug crews turned the Ingersoll
title: Dozens Indicted in Crackdown on a Brooklyn Drug Ring

body: The German beer gardens and singing clubs have long been silent. The breweries, from Otto Huber and Kings to Rheingold and Schaefer, closed down decades ago. And the yeasty-sweet smell of flowing lager and ale saturating Brewer's Row has been replaced almost entirely with the many odors of contemporary urban industrial life. But even though
title: King of Beer? Not Anymore. But Keep the Mugs Cold.

body: The terra cotta cherubs are getting new little fingers and noses. Some of the 22 full-size lions' heads have been reconstructed, and all have been cleaned. But best of all, the Brooklyn Academy of Music is getting its cornice back. Once 280 feet long and 15 feet high, the richly ornamented crown of the 1908 opera house and concert hall had gone
title: A Brooklyn Landmark Gets Its Crown Back; At Music Academy, Color Supplants Grime

body: WITH the exception of the mayor and a stray actor or two, the subway trains are generally bereft of public figures. It's an anonymous journey. This is not the case on the F train, however, where every day a luminary rides alongside the commuters in the form of a small, sweet-natured old panhandler named Sonny Payne. Sonny has worked the F train so
title: The Ballad Of Sonny Payne

body: Daniel L. Doctoroff has recorded a personal best time of 21 minutes and 3 seconds bicycling from his Upper West Side brownstone to City Hall. He has noted the 22 consecutive days he has not lost his temper, as well as the 615 plants, trees and shrubs that would be affected by his plans to redevelop the West Side of Manhattan. He makes sure that
title: A True Champion Of Grand Plans And Tiny Details; With the Zeal of an Athlete, Doctoroff Pursues Olympics

body: While prices for brownstones in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn have doubled in the last five years to an average of $600,000, rents at Restoration Plaza, the retail and cultural center at the heart of the neighborhood, lag far behind. Now there is an initial $10 million effort under way to turn around the lackluster 330,000-square-foot
title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Brooklyn; Effort to Revive Retail Plaza Gains in Bedford-Stuyvesant

body: THERE is a reason that Kenneth Adams is called Mr. Brooklyn, though he demurs that this honorific is inappropriate. title: PUBLIC LIVES; If Brooklyn's Your Borough, Then He's Your Guy

body: On Columbia Street along the Brooklyn waterfront stands a single sign announcing Irving Street. Except that, conventionally speaking, these
title: When the Street Name Outlives the Street; Only Signs Remain to Tell the Story Of New York's Ever-Changing Grid

author: ANDY NEWMAN is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times.
body: THE Brooklyn Bridge is no longer the longest suspension bridge ever built; it's not even the longest suspension bridge that goes to Brooklyn. title: AMERICAN CITIES: NEW YORK; Spanning the Skyline

title: Arena Developer Rethinking Condemnation of Houses

title: Suburban Retailing for the New Brooklyn

body: Former M.T.A. Chief Is Multi-Tasking at 70 ''Are you kidding?'' Richard Ravitch said last week when asked whether he was thinking of retiring. Actually, it was more like, ''Are you kidding!!'' title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; For a Place With a Future, an Eye to the Past

title: Prosecutors Say Rescuer Stole Cars Recovered At Ground Zero

body: One summer day in 1968, Mayor John V. title: Bloomberg Plans Overhaul of Creaky 911 System

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; From Graffiti's Cutting Edge To Painting Aaliyah on a Purse

title: Blue Skies and Green Yards, All Lost to Red Ink

title: Let the Hosannas Resound With the Joyful Spirit of Easter

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: City Sells Garage For $6 Million

body: Like Wall Street and Delancey Street, Atlantic Avenue is one of those New York thoroughfares whose names conjure up distinctive worlds, in its case an incongruous mix of a Middle Eastern bazaar where you can actually buy frankincense and myrrh and a row of Victorian antique shops. A livelier Atlantic Avenue has been shaking off that stereotype for
title: Brooklyn's Mile-Long Makeover; Atlantic Avenue Is at the Heart of Plans for a Pier, Arena and Park

title: New Theater For Brooklyn Arts District

title: Streetscapes/Robert Gair, Dumbo and Brooklyn; Neighborhood's Past Incised in Its Facades

title: Firefighter in Crash Took Cocaine, City Says

title: PRO BASKETBALL; Move Looms, but Nets Fans Aren't Ready to Let Go Just Yet

title: For Exercise in New York Futility, Push Button

In a deal with prosecutors in Criminal Court in Brooklyn, Mr. Tyson agreed
title: Tyson Agrees to Plea Deal In Hotel Fight, Avoiding Jail

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Off-Duty Officer Arrested In Altercation

title: Man Guilty Of Lying To the F.B.I. In Sheik Case

title: Rock Thrown by Truck Hits Windshield, Killing Brooklyn Woman, 77

title: Proposed Arena: Location, Location

title: Sorrow and Anger Linger as Brooklyn Buries Two Boys Killed by Truck

body: Call it the Valentine's Day massacre. Lutèce and Gage & Tollner, two historic restaurants that for decades had attained almost the status of civic institutions, will shut their doors on the same day, tomorrow. Another, La Côte Basque, will follow early next month. Hands wring. Diners mourn. The New is cursed. Doom is inferred. Darkness descends.
title: Eat and Be Merry; Tomorrow 2 Classics Die

body: The police officer who shot and killed an unarmed 19-year-old last month on the roof of a Brooklyn housing project told a grand jury yesterday that he did not remember raising his weapon and pulling the trigger, according to two people familiar with his testimony, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. In testimony before the 23-member grand
title: Officer Said To Tell Jury He Can't Recall Fatal Shooting

body: The Rev. John Powis tends to what he calls his ''church without walls,'' since its most vulnerable parishioners live without ceilings, heat or water. The informal Brooklyn congregation -- mostly elderly widows or immigrant families facing eviction from crumbling buildings -- is his way of fighting off the boredom of retirement and the creeping
title: CITYWIDE; Retirement Gives Him His Finest Ministry

title: Streetscapes/The Sutton, 57th Street Near Third Avenue; Movie Theater's Facade Undergoes a Drastic Change

title: To Avoid Competing With Garden, Jets Redraw Plans for Stadium on West Side

title: Sports of The Times; And the Heads Keep on Falling Around the City

body: IN 1884, when major league baseball came to Brooklyn, it could be said that Brooklyn, even then jockeying for attention in the shadow of Manhattan, needed the team more than the team needed Brooklyn. title: Ideas & Trends; Brooklyn, the Borough That Begs for Nothing

title: PRO BASKETBALL; Ratner's Path To Buy Nets Had Pitfalls And Promise

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; To Some, the Nets Are a Slam Dunk, to Others a Technical Foul

body: IS the ghost of Robert Moses still haunting New York? Last Sunday was the 70th anniversary of the appointment of Robert Moses as the city's parks commissioner. He was by far its longest-serving commissioner -- 26 years -- from January 1934 to May 1960. Only Henry Stern's 15 years came close. Every parks commissioner since Moses has served in his
title: COPING; Amid News Of the Nets, Memories Of Moses

body: To the Sports Editor: In response to George Vecsey's column about Brooklyn (''Dodgers Moved On; Nets Could Move In,'' Jan. 22), I must say there is a distinct disconnect between his perception of what is going on here and the reality of life here. Vecsey's reference to downtown Brooklyn as ''iffy'' is a sad misrepresentation of the area. Brooklyn
title: Brooklyn Doesn't Need Nets To Provide It With Identity

body: To the Sports Editor: Brooklyn hasn't waited for the Nets to dream again. For the past 15 years, the borough has grown in leaps and bounds, restoring both an identity and a good quality of life, and this despite obstacles like cuts in the city's budget. It's galling to see that public funds much needed for schools, health care and the arts may go
title: Brooklyn Doesn't Need Nets To Provide It With Identity; Misplaced Priorities

Ratner had won the bidding for the New Jersey Nets with plans to install them in a new home near downtown Brooklyn. ''It's exciting,'' said Mr. Markowitz, the borough president. ''It puts Brooklyn back in the big leagues.'' But
title: Bid for a Brooklyn Sports Complex Faces Challenges From All Sides

body: IF I hear one more ode to the old Brooklyn Dodgers or to Ebbets Field or to Pee Wee and Jackie, I'll scream. I'm screaming now, but it's hard to hear because of the roar of misplaced celebration. All the excited talk surrounding the agreement Wednesday to sell the Nets and eventually move the franchise to Brooklyn would have you think that the
title: Sports of The Times; Nets Have Their Place, But It Isn't Brooklyn

McGreevey insisted that New Jersey would be better off losing the franchise than spending tens of millions of tax dollars to keep it. title: In New Jersey, an Uncertain Political Response to the Sale

body: NOBODY better understands how long and potentially painful the Nets' road from New Jersey to Brooklyn might be than a man who has taken many a labored step with them, from that night in 1967 when they opened the doors to the Teaneck Armory. The Nets were called the New Jersey Americans and the opponents in that now-ancient American Basketball
title: Sports of The Times; He Tracks Nets' Moves, On the Court And Off It

body: Before the first N.B.A. tipoff at the gleaming arena that the developer Bruce C. Ratner envisions for the area straddling the Atlantic Avenue rail yards, Mr. Ratner will have to take on a scrappy squad from down the block: his neighbors. A more ethnically, economically and commercially diverse crew would be hard to assemble, even in New York City.
title: Guarding Their Homes Against the Bulldozer

body: UNTIL now, basketball in Brooklyn mostly meant schoolyard courts or the high school gyms where teenagers learned to shoot and pass, to dunk and defend. You could dream about playing for the Knicks at the Garden, but if you had big-time talent, you had to go away to a college out there in the sticks where you knew you would feel like a stranger.
title: Sports of The Times; Brooklyn Crosses Bridge Back Into the Big Time

body: Contrary to popular belief, Brooklyn did not die when a rich man named Walter O'Malley took away the Dodgers after the 1957 baseball season. Brooklyn is still there. From the edge of the South Street Seaport in Manhattan, gazing east, you can see a silhouette of towers, bridges, piers and steeples that would take your breath away if they suddenly
title: Sports of The Times; A New Bounce in Brooklyn's Step

body: Bruce C. Ratner, the developer who wants to move the New Jersey Nets to downtown Brooklyn, reached an agreement yesterday to buy the team for $300 million, defeating a similar offer by Charles Kushner and Senator Jon S. Corzine, the team said. There is no guarantee that Mr. Ratner will be able to fulfill his vision in Brooklyn, where sports fans
title: PRO BASKETBALL: OVERVIEW; Nets Are Sold for $300 Million, And Dream Grows in Brooklyn

body: He could go down as the avenger of Walter O'Malley. All right, partial avenger. It's impossible to imagine the treasonous Walter O'Malley ever being forgiven for transplanting the Dodgers from Brooklyn to Los Angeles after the 1957 season. But by importing a New Jersey basketball team to the borough, Bruce C. Ratner, himself a childhood Cleveland
title: PRO BASKETBALL: THE BUYER; Can Former Indians Fan Be O'Malley's Avenger?

body: Perry McLaughlin, part-time student, longtime Knicks fan, 39-year-old Brooklyn resident, tried to absorb the news as he stood in front of New York City College of Technology in downtown Brooklyn yesterday. The New Jersey Nets had been bought by a man determined to move them to Brooklyn. There was a sense of celebration, yes, but of competing
title: PRO BASKETBALL: THE STREET; Fans in the City Feeling the Tug From a Rivalry

body: Bruce C. Ratner and Charles Kushner raised their bids modestly yesterday in their competition to buy the Nets, and officials involved in the negotiations said the process was moving rapidly toward a conclusion that could come as early as today. Ratner wants to move the team to downtown Brooklyn, and Kushner's intent is to keep the Nets playing in
title: PRO BASKETBALL; Bidding for the Nets Is Down to the Wire

body: IF ever there was a telltale sign of what it means to be the New Jersey Nets, it has come these last few weeks, from the moment Isiah Thomas became the Knicks' new head chef and began making chicken salad at Madison Square Garden. Remember that storm between Jason Kidd and Byron Scott? Alonzo Mourning's brave struggle for survival? The fluid,
title: Sports of The Times; If Stern Is Rooting, It Must Be for Brooklyn

body: FLICKERING before Amanda M. Burden, the city planning commissioner, was a vision of New York City of the future. A computer animation showed the view from a car driving toward the Greenpoint waterfront in Brooklyn. The industrial buildings were gone, replaced by a stately procession of five- and six-story brick and stone apartment buildings,
title: Remaking, or Preserving, the City's Face

body: In the remaining two-bidder race to acquire the Nets, the question of how close a final deal is has taken center stage. The president of the Nets' ownership group, Edwin Stier, said yesterday that no deal was imminent. ''We are carrying on parallel negotiations with prospective purchasers,'' he said, with the goal of completing them ''as rapidly as
title: PRO BASKETBALL; Nets' Ownership Says Sale of Team Is Not Imminent

body: The developer Bruce C. Ratner, who wants to buy the Nets and move them to Brooklyn, has been in exclusive negotiations with the team's owners since Monday, an executive involved in the negotiations said last night. title: PRO BASKETBALL; Nets Focus On Bidder With Ties In Brooklyn

body: To the Editor: I live on the border between downtown Brooklyn and Boerum Hill, directly across the street from the area of proposed development described in ''Plugging a Hole in Brooklyn's Heart'' (news article, Jan. 7). I've never thought of the view from my front door as ''eight square blocks of urban blight.'' Instead, I've enjoyed looking at
title: A Song of Queens, a Dream in Brooklyn

body: IN a darkened bay at Red Hook's watery edge, the trolley guy of Brooklyn steps over the bits and pieces of his grand vision to board his magnificent vessel. Come on, he says, in that weary-whiny voice of his. ''I'll take you on the world's shortest trolley ride.'' He turns on the lights, rings the bell -- ding, ding -- and an 1897 trolley of
title: About New York; The Trolley Guy's Last Ride (All 12 Feet of It)

body: A fire lieutenant who was transferred after a fight on New Year's Eve at a Staten Island firehouse was suspended for drinking and fighting on the job in 1986. The lieutenant, Gregory McFarland, who was working at Engine Company 151 and Ladder Company 76 in Tottenville when the fight occurred on New Year's Eve, was reassigned by the Fire Department
title: Fire Lieutenant Reassigned From S.I. Was Suspended After 1986 Fight

body: Charles Kushner, a member of one of the groups bidding for the Nets, said yesterday that he may raise his bid of $267.5 million to narrow the gap between his offer and that of Bruce C. Ratner, who has bid $300 million. The sale process, now in its fourth month, features Kushner, whose lead partner is Senator Jon S. Corzine, Democrat of New Jersey;
title: BASKETBALL; Kushner Says He May Raise Bid For Nets to Closer to $300 Million

body: Brooklyn nurses its grudge against Manhattan with all the subtlety of King Kong, a Red Sox fan or Gerald R. Ford.
